Robson & one of its glaciers calving into Berg Lake | map = Canada British Columbia | relief = yes | map_width = 240 | map_caption = Location of ''Mount Robson Provincial Park'' in [[Canada]] | location = [[British Columbia]], [[Canada]] | nearest_city = [[Valemount, British Columbia|Valemount]], [[Jasper, Alberta|Jasper]] | lat_d = 53 | lat_m = 02 | lat_s = 02 | lat_NS = N | long_d = 119 | long_m = 13 | long_s = 54 | long_EW = W | area = 2,249 km² | established = 1913 | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | governing_body = [[BC Parks]] }} '''Mount Robson Provincial Park''' is a large provincial park in the [[Canadian Rockies]] with an area of 2,249 km². The park is located entirely within [[British Columbia]], bordering [[Jasper National Park]] in [[Alberta]]. The B.C. legislature created the park in 1913, the same year as the first ascent of [[Mount Robson]] by a party led by [[Conrad Kain]]. The park is named for Mount Robson, which has the highest point in the Canadian Rockies and is located entirely within the park. [[File:Kinney lake2.jpg|thumb|left|Reflections of mountains in [[Kinney Lake]]]] [[File:Yellowhead Lake.jpg|thumb|upright=1.5|[[Yellowhead Lake]]]] The first recreational trail was built in 1913 by Jasper outfitter Donald "Curly" Phillips along the [[Robson River]] to [[Berg Lake]]. From May to September, a visitor centre is open just south of the Mt. Robson Viewpoint on the [[Yellowhead Highway]]. The only services within the park are at a combination coffee-shop gas station complex at the Viewpoint. To reach the park, follow the [[Yellowhead Highway]] 390 kilometres west of [[Edmonton, Alberta|Edmonton]] or 290 kilometres east of [[Prince George, British Columbia|Prince George]].<br style="clear:left;" /> ==World Heritage Site== In 1990 Mount Robson Park was included within the [[Canadian Rocky Mountain Parks]] [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage Site]].<ref>{{cite web | date=1990 | title=World Heritage Committee: Fourteenth Session | publisher=UNESCO | url=http://whc.unesco.org/archive/repcom90.htm | accessdate=24 June 2012}}</ref> Together with the other [[national parks|national]] and [[provincial park]]s that comprise the Canadian Rocky Mountain Parks, the park was recognized for its natural beauty and the geological and ecological significance of its mountain landscapes containing the habitats of rare and endangered species, mountain peaks, [[glacier]]s, lakes, waterfalls, [[canyon]]s, limestone caves and fossils. ==See also== *[[List of British Columbia Provincial Parks]] *[[List of Canadian provincial parks]] *[[List of National Parks of Canada]] *[[List of World Heritage Sites in the Americas]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commonscat}} *[http://www.env.gov.bc.ca/bcparks/explore/parkpgs/mtrobson.html BC Parks] - Mount Robson Provincial Park website {{World Heritage Sites in Canada}} {{Canadian Rockies|state=collapsed}} [[Category:Parks in the Canadian Rockies]] [[Category:Provincial Parks of British Columbia]] [[Category:Robson Valley]]
